model_input:
[Task Description]
You will be given DIALOGUE CONTEXT and MEMORY.
Your job is to judge if MEMORY contains helpful past information for a language model, representing Unknown, to generate a proper next response based on DIALOGUE CONTEXT.

If the DIALOUGE CONTEXT does not require the model to utilize past information for response generation, say "N/A".
Say "Yes" if MEMORY contains such helpful information and say "No" if it dose not.
Provide a brief explanation for your judgement.

[Format Regulation]
Generate your output below OUTPUT using the following format:
Brief explanation: your explanation
Judgement: "Yes", "No", or "N/A"

[Task]
DIALOGUE CONTEXT:
Thank you for finding my glasses for me, Mentor. I always seem to misplace them.
Not a problem, Mentee. I'm glad I could help. 
This actually reminds me of when I was struggling with substance abuse. I would often lose things or forget where I put things because of my drinking. It's amazing how much clearer my mind is now that I'm sober.
That's a great observation, Mentee. Sobriety can definitely improve your cognitive abilities and overall wellbeing. It's amazing how much substance abuse can hold us back in life.
Yeah, it's definitely a difficult journey, but I'm grateful for the support systems I have in place. Like you, Mentor. Your experience and guidance have been invaluable to me.
I'm happy to be there for you, Mentee. It's been great seeing you grow and develop over the years.
Speaking of growth, I've been really trying to live in the moment lately. It's been bringing me so much joy and fulfillment, and I feel more connected to the world around me.
That's fantastic, Mentee. Being present and mindful can do wonders for your mental health and overall satisfaction with life. Keep it up!
I definitely will, Mentor. And thanks again for finding my glasses. Your help means a lot to me.

[MEMORY]
Related Evidences: (1) {'Related Topics': 'Personal history of substance abuse', 'Related Summaries': 'Mentee opens up about their past substance abuse and journey to sobriety with Mentor.', 'Related Dialogues': '### Mentee: Mentor, I wanted to talk to you about my personal history of substance abuse. It's something I'm not proud of, but it's a part of my past that I can't change. ### Mentor: Of course, Mentee. I'm here to listen and support you. Could you tell me more about your experience with substance abuse? ### Mentee: Sure. I started drinking when I was 15, and it quickly became a habit. It was a way to escape from my problems and feel better about myself. But over time, the drinking got worse, and I started using other substances too. It was a downward spiral, and I didn't know how to stop. ### Mentor: That sounds incredibly tough, Mentee. I imagine that getting sober was not an easy journey. ### Mentee: It definitely wasn't. I had to confront a lot of difficult emotions and learn how to cope with them in healthy ways. But now that I'm sober, I feel so much better about myself. I don't wake up feeling ashamed or guilty anymore, and I can focus on building a better life for myself. ### Mentor: That's amazing, Mentee. Congratulations on your sobriety. I'm so proud of the progress you've made. ### Mentee: Thank you, Mentor. I couldn't have done it without your guidance and support. It's been a journey, but I know that staying sober is the right choice for me. ### Mentor: I'm always here for you, Mentee. If you ever need to talk or want some advice, don't hesitate to reach out. And remember, living in the moment and savoring each moment of your sober life can help you stay focused and motivated on your journey.  ### Mentee: Thank you so much, Mentor. I appreciate your encouragement and am looking forward to continuing to embrace the present moment.' }(2) {'Related Topics': 'Living in the moment', 'Related Summaries': 'Mentee shares the positive impact of living in the moment with Mentor.', 'Related Dialogues': '### Mentee: Mentor, I've been trying to live in the moment lately. It's been such an incredible experience, and I'm feeling so much more connected to my life. ### Mentor: I'm so glad to hear that, Mentee. How have you been doing it? ### Mentee: Just paying attention to the little things that I used to take for granted. When I'm eating, for example, I try to really savor the tastes and textures of the food. And when I'm outside, I try to notice all the small details - the way the sunlight is streaming through the leaves of the trees, the sounds of the birds singing, and the feel of the breeze on my skin. ### Mentor: That's a great approach. It's amazing how much more you can appreciate your life when you slow down and pay attention to the things that matter. ### Mentee: Absolutely. I used to feel so overwhelmed all the time, like life was just passing me by. But now that I'm living in the moment, I feel like I'm really experiencing everything fully. It's brought me so much joy and fulfillment. ### Mentor: That's wonderful to hear. Keep up the good work, Mentee. And remember, as you continue on this path, there will be moments when you slip back into your old patterns. But that's okay - just notice when it happens, and gently bring your attention back to the present moment. ### Mentee: Thank you for the reminder, Mentor. I definitely feel like this is a lifelong practice, but I'm excited to keep exploring it. ' }
```
